factoid: The narrator has just returned from his benefactor.
The narrator hastened to write down what he has experienced.
Joseph Alexéevich is living poorly.
Joseph Alexéevich has been suffering from a painful bladder disease for three years.
No one has ever heard Joseph Alexéevich utter a groan or a word of complaint.
From morning until late at night, except when he eats plain food, Joseph Alexéevich works at science.
Joseph Alexéevich received the narrator graciously.
Joseph Alexéevich made the narrator sit down on the bed on which he lay.
The narrator made the sign of the Knights of the East and of Jerusalem.
Joseph Alexéevich responded in the same manner.
Joseph Alexéevich asked the narrator with a mild smile what he had learned and gained in the Prussian and Scottish lodges.
The narrator told Joseph Alexéevich everything as best he could.
The narrator told Joseph Alexéevich what he had proposed to the Petersburg lodge.
The narrator told Joseph Alexéevich about the bad reception he had encountered.
The narrator told Joseph Alexéevich about his rupture with the Brothers.
Joseph Alexéevich remained silent and thoughtful for a good while.
Joseph Alexéevich told the narrator his view of the matter.
Joseph Alexéevich's view illuminated the narrator's whole past and the future path he should follow.
Joseph Alexéevich surprised the narrator by asking whether he remembered the threefold aim of the order.

The threefold aim of the order are: (1) the preservation and study of the mystery, (2) the purification and reformation of oneself for its reception, and (3) the improvement of the human race by striving for such purification.
The principal aim of these three aims is self-reformation and self-purification.
Only to this aim can we always strive independently of circumstances.
At the same time, this aim demands the greatest efforts of us.

Led astray by pride and losing sight of this aim, people occupy themselves either with the mystery which, in our impurity, we are unworthy to receive, or seek the reformation of the human race while ourselves setting an example of baseness and profligacy.
Illuminism is not a pure doctrine because it is attracted by social activity and puffed up by pride.
On this ground, Joseph Alexéevich condemned the narrator's speech and whole activity.
The narrator agreed with Joseph Alexéevich in the depth of his soul.
Joseph Alexéevich said that the chief duty of a true Mason lies in perfecting himself.
Joseph Alexéevich said that by removing all difficulties of life we shall more quickly reach our aim.
Joseph Alexéevich said that only in the midst of worldly cares we can attain our three chief aims.
The three chief aims are: (1) self-knowledge, (2) self-perfecting, and (3) the attainment of the chief virtue—love of death.
Only the vicissitudes of life can show us its vanity and develop our innate love of death or of rebirth to a new life.
Joseph Alexéevich is never weary of life although he loves death.
Joseph Alexéevich does not yet feel himself sufficiently prepared to love death.
The narrator's benefactor explained the meaning of the Great Square of creation.
The narrator's benefactor pointed out that the numbers three and seven are the basis of everything.
The narrator's benefactor advised him not to avoid intercourse with the Petersburg Brothers.
The narrator's benefactor advised him to take up only second-grade posts in the lodge.
The narrator's benefactor advised him to try to divert the Brothers from pride.
The narrator's benefactor advised him to turn the Brothers toward the true path of self-knowledge and self-perfecting.
The narrator's benefactor advised him personally above all to keep a watch over himself.
The narrator's benefactor gave him a notebook.
The narrator is now writing in the notebook.
The narrator will in future note down all his actions in the notebook.
The date of the narrator's account is 23 November.
